titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I was employed in the forenoon; writing for Mr: Apthorp— Called on him this afternoon, to shew him the sketch I had drawn up, which he approved.— At my father’s— Read a Chapter of Aristotle’s Rhetoric— Mrs: Harrod came with my brother from Boston; on a visit to her daughter— In the Evening at home I read a couple of Chapter’s of Marshall’s introductory Volume— Mrs: Adams still unwell.

2. Finished Mr: Apthorp’s papers, and carried them to him— Dined with the Club at his House— All there excepting Mr Black.— After dinner I went to my father’s and spent a couple of hours— Evening at home; and read the first Act of Othello— The language of which has more of the peculiarities of its ages, than most of Shakespeare’s other plays.

3. Heard Mr: Ely; in the morning, from Romans II.6. and in the Afternoon from Jeremiah VIII.22.— I have formerly characterized this Gentleman’s manner, and have no new observation to make upon it. Dined with him at my father’s; and with all my family— In the afternoon Mrs: Swan, and Miss Breck were there— They came out from Boston; and returned early in the Evening. I wrote to G. Thayer, to send by my brother to-morrow.— Read Sterne’s Sermons XXXII. XXXIII. and XXXIV. The first of which is an anniversary Sermon, on the 30th: of January.— The second on the tardiness of divine retribution, and the third on Trust in God— They are not equal to many of the preceding ones; and their composition is yet more careless and incorrect— In the Evening, I read a couple of chapters in Marshall.

4. My father’s family being all absent but himself at Hingham and Boston, he came and dined with us— I went with him in the afternoon to his house— Before I came home, my mother & brother had returned, as had W. Smith, with Louisa, from Cambridge— Mr: T. Greenleaf was at my father’s— I read a Chapter of Aristotle’s Rhetoric; and in the Evening, a Chapter of Marshall’s introductory Volume—

5. I walked this afternoon to Neponsit Bridge to attend the monthly meeting of the Directors; but only Mr: Greenleaf and Captain Beale were there, so that a Quorum could not be formed— We adjourned to Captain Beale’s house to-morrow afternoon, 4 O’Clock— I was at my father’s the greater part of the Evening— Employed part of the day in packing up my books.

6. I walk’d up this morning with Mr: French, and Mr: Briesler, and went round the boundaries of the wood-lots sold me, by my father— There is on great part of it no fence between me and Mr: Bracket my next neighbour. A large pine tree standing in the gap between two walls, and on which Mr: French says the number of the lot was marked has been cut down by a trespasser— The stump alone now remains. from this the line northward is marked by heaps of stones at small distances— One other pine tree stands in the direct course— The line passes through the centre of that Tree, and I marked an A. on my side of it, which I carved with a penknife— I also went with Briesler round the bounds, on all that part of my farm— We were three hours on the tour— In the afternoon, I called on Mr: Apthorp, and went with him to Captain Beale’s, where we formed at length a Quorum of the Bridge-Directors and chose a Committee to transact the Affairs of the Bridge through the Winter. Before I returned home, I stop’d an hour at my father’s—who informed me that there is one of the three wood-lots, which he sold me, that I did not visit this morning; it being separated from my other lots by Mr: Bracket’s. In the Evening, I finished reading the introductory Volume, to Marshall’s life of Washington.

7. I went to Boston this morning, and took George with me, to consult Dr: Welsh, on his complaints— I saw Mr: Boylston at Mr: Shaw’s Office, and had some conversation with him, on business which he wishes to have transacted.— At the Insurance Office, I saw Judge Davis, who informed me that the Corporation and Overseers, had pass’d a vote to agree to the proposals made in my two letters respecting the Professorship— The Rules and Regulations are to be modified accordingly.— I met Mr: Davenport, and had some further Conversation with him, respecting his House, beyond West-Boston-Bridge; but came to no final determination— Dined at Dr: Welsh’s— After dinner, I called at Mr H. G. Otis’s, for Eliza Johnson, and soon after, took her there— We returned to Quincy early in the Evening.

8. Mrs: Adams and Eliza Johnson went to Boston this morning, and took John with them— They returned early in the afternoon. After employing the morning principally in arranging papers and preparing for departure I went to my father’s after dinner, and there finished the perusal and analysis of Aristotle’s three Books on Rhetoric.— It detained me later than usual— Returning home I stopp’d at Mr: Cranch’s. I am to leave my eldest son, George there, for the winter.— John, the youngest, my mother has agreed to take. Mrs: Cranch is to have $2:50. per week for George’s board.

9. The greatest part of the day we were all engaged in packing up furniture, and preparing for our departure— Mr: Boylston came out from Boston and dined with us— William Smith also was here. In the afternoon I went with Mr: Boylston to my father’s, and took George with me— Mr: Boylston soon returned to Jamaica Plains— George, I left at my father’s— Mr: Davenport came out with Mr: Shaw from Boston; and made me some further proposals respecting his house— But we came to no final determination. I came home late— This day I settled most of my Accounts; and bills.

10. Heavy rain all the morning detained us at home— We dined all at my father’s, and spent the afternoon there. My brother went to Boston and returned before we came away— His object was to see his friend S. Nicholas. Mr: Davenport called again this Evening; and Mr: Shaw returned with him to Boston— We left both the children at my father’s; and as we came home stopp’d at Mr: Cranch’s; where we saw Mr: Quincy’s child— George is to go there to-morrow from school.— We propose to depart early to-morrow morning.

11. At six this morning, a carriage came out for us from Boston, and we immediately, Mrs: Adams, Eliza Johnson, and myself, took our departure. At My father’s we stopp’d and took up my Sister, her son William, her daughter Caroline and Rose— At 8 O’Clock we left my father’s; entered on the Turnpike Road at Dedham— Dined at Wrentham; where we found Mr: Otis, who came also from Boston this morning; and is going on to Washington— We arrived at Ammidon’s, Providence between 5 and 6 in the Evening; and found a Packet ready to sail; waiting only for us. We engaged our passages and are to embark in the morning— Mr: Morris, by whom I sent the message for the Packet, called upon us in the Evening.

12. At 9 this morning, we embarked on board the packet, Polly, Captain Justin; and at about 11. Sailed with a fair but light wind, which soon failed; it was our intention to have gone out by what is called the West Passage, without touching at Newport at-all— But the wind in the afternoon and evening proving unfavourable, we were obliged to go in to Newport harbour and anchored there for the Night.— Our fellow-passengers are Mr: Otis—Mr: Cross and Mr: Clark of Portland; and a Mr: Mudge

13. The wind this morning was light and unfavourable, but Captain Justin determined to proceed; we accordingly sailed at 8 in the o’clock; and after beating against the wind, and lying becalmed, we finally came to anchor under Point Judith at 5 in the afternoon— Here we remained about two hours during which the Captain and some of the Passengers went on shore. Between 7 and 8 a breeze from the North-East sprung up, and we immediately made sail— Soon after midnight we came in sight of the New-London Light-House— There was a light fall of Snow, and the weather for a short time was so threatening, that the Captain had determined to go in to New-London harbour— But after the moon-rose, the sky soon cleared off, and we continued our course— I was up untill 2. in the morning.

14. Our wind continued favourable through the Night and this day untill about noon, when we reached the entrance of the Sound, at Sanders’s point— Here it suddenly died away, and the weather became so thick and hazy, that by the time night came on we had not reached nearer than 5 miles of the Passage of Hell-gate, where we were obliged to anchor for the Night.

15— We came through Hell-gate about nine this morning, with foul-weather, and rain, and a very light head wind— About noon we reached New-York; my Sister with her family being now at home; and we accompanied them to their house—the Packet Polly, is the smallest and most inconvenient vessel of all those concerned in this
trade, and was more indifferently provided than I have ever found them; but she has far the best Captain, for effecting a speedy passage; for he has no propensities to stop at Newport, and came out with us from that place with a head-wind— This probably shortened our passage as much as two days; for it enabled us to take the full benefit of the North-eastern breeze, which lasted just long enough to bring us through the sound— At Newport we found another packet, with thirty passengers, ready to sail, but waiting for a wind— She did not sail when we did, because the wind was a-head; consequently we arrive at New-York, one or two days earlier— This zeal of Captain Justin, for accomplishing his passage, is a strong recommendation in his favour.— In the Evening I called on Mr: M’Cormick, and on Mr: King, with whom I found the celebrated General Miranda.

16. Having nothing to do, I pass’d the day partly in walking the Streets, and partly in inspecting the volumes of engravings and the coloured drawings, presented by the Emperor Napoleon to the Academy of Arts in this City; which are deposited at Coll: Smith’s house, and which are well worthy of more time than I have to bestow upon them.— I engaged seats in the Diligence Stage, which goes for Philadelphia, at 8 o’clock on Monday Morning.

17. I went to the presbyterian Church in Wall-Street this morning, with the hopes of hearing Dr: Miller; but the preacher was Dr: Smith, President of the College at Princeton— His Sermon was from Genesis 22. v. 2. on the Sacrifice of Isaac— A difficult subject— Dr: Smith is a very good writer, and a very handsome Speaker— There is an Affectation of Grace and Elegance in his Manner, which must be to him a second Nature; for he had it when I first heard him in Boston, fifteen years since, as much as he has it now.— Met Mr: Hunt, the member of Congress from New-Hampshire, after Church, at the door— After dinner I took a ride with Coll: Smith, to see his friend Coll: Willet, to whom we paid a short visit. Mrs: King called to see the Ladies; I attended her home and pass’d the Evening with Mr: King.

18. At 8 o’clock this morning we cross’d the ferry at Paulus Hoek, with a blustering North-West Wind, which made the passage very unpleasant. We immediately took the Stage, and after dining at Woodbridge, reached Princeton, 54 miles from Paulus Hoek, at about 7. in the Evening.— We were desirous to have stopp’d at Newark, long enough to have call’d on Coll: Smith’s mother, and Mrs: Charles Adams; but the Stage would not stay for us; and we were obliged to pass through. we lodge at Gifford’s in Princeton.

19. Just after day-break this morning, we resumed our Seats in the Stage— Breakfasted at Trenton; and arrived at Philadelphia, 42 miles from Princeton, just after two O’Clock P.M. The driver took us to Mrs: Roberts’s, where we have always lodged heretofore; but her house is now so full that she could not receive us— We then came to Mrs: Decharms’s, Market-Street, near the corner of fifth Street. N.where we found lodgings— Mr: and Mrs: Turnbull, with whom we became acquainted last Spring, when we went through this City, are also here. In the afternoon I called at Mr: Ewing’s Office, and saw Mrs: Rutter, who is still confined with a pleurisy to her chamber— In the Evening, I was so much fatigued and unwell, that I very early retired from the Company at our lodgings, to-bed— Among our fellow-passengers in the stage from New-York, was Mr: Clark, who came with us from Providence; and a Mr: Wood, an Englishman; and a man of incessant Tongue.

20. Foul weather, confined us great part of the day to our own lodgings; but I dined at Mr: Rutter’s, where I met Mr: Hopkinson, and Mr: Ewing— Mr: Richard Rush came in after dinner. I called to see Mr: Dennie, and also at Dr: Rush’s—but found neither of them at home. Mr: and Mrs: Hopkinson came to see our Ladies in the Evening— We find our accommodations very good— Our fellow lodgers are Mr: & Mrs: Turnbull; his Aunt Mrs: Elliott—Mr: Travers an Englishman, & his wife, a French Lady; & two Miss Morris’s daughters of Coll: Morris, of New-York.

21. Called on T. Allibone & Son, corner of Water & Sassafras or Race Streets— And on Dobson. N: 41. South Second Street. to execute certain orders from my father— At Mr: Meredith’s I met Mr: Dennie, and walk’d with them to see the building they are erecting for an Academy of Arts; which is small, but will be neat and elegant— We called to see Mr: Quincy, but found he had proceeded this morning on his Journey to Washington. Dined at Mr: Hopkinson’s with Messrs: Ewing, Meredith, Turnbull and Dennie— We also spent the Evening there with the Ladies—

22. Called this morning at Mr: Breck’s; who came in yesterday from the Country— Mr: Geyer came in while I was there— I dined at Mr: Meredith’s, with Messrs: Hopkinson, Dennie, Ewing, and R. Peters— We sat untill quite into the Evening, and had much agreeable literary conversation.

23. I called on Mr. Dennie this morning at his lodgings, and pass’d a couple of hours with him— Saw Mr: Dorsey, the Treasurer of the Schuylkill Bridge Company.— Mr: and Mrs: Breck, called to see the Ladies at our lodgings— We all dined at Dr: Rush’s; and I spent the Evening, with Mr: Ewing, at Mr: Hopkinson’s— We sat in conversation, untill Mr: Ewing reminded us that it was Sunday Morning.

24. I went with Mr: Ewing this forenoon to the presbyterian meeting-house, of which his father was formerly the Minister— The preacher was a very young Man; and a very poor speaker and writer— On returning home I found Miss Morton visiting the Ladies. Dr: Chapman called on me and accompanied me to the Hospital; an establishment supported by private subscriptions and donations; principally by the quakers— I had seen it before, in July 1794. when Dr: Wistar accompanied me there. It remains much in the same State, as it was in at that time— Excepting a Statue of Penn, in the front yard, which has lately been received and placed there— The anatomical preparations have been in some degree damaged in the course of eleven years, and have received no new additions— I dined at Mr: Breck’s; but the Ladies, owing to indispositions & the badness of the weather sent excuses— At Mr: Breck’s I met Mr: John Vaughan, Mr: Geyer, and two sons of Judge Wilson— In the Evening I called, and spent an hour at Mr: Hopkinson’s; where I found Mr: Ewing.

25. I had engaged our passage in the Newcastle Packet, Rising Sun, the same in which we came from that place last Spring. The hour fixed for her departure was 7 in the morning, and the Captain said half an hour was allowed for all the passengers to get on board. I went down to the Packet before 7. and saw our baggage safely stowed on board. Then returned to Mrs: Decharms’s to breakfast, and to attend the Ladies; but when we came down to the wharf; the packet had left it about five minutes; and with a wind so fair, that although she was still within hailing distance of the wharf, we could not get a boat to take us on board— We were therefore compelled to return to our lodgings, and content ourselves with remaining another day at Philadelphia. At the corner of Water-Street, as we returned; we met Mr: Tracy, who like us was going in the Packet, and lost his passage by being belated— My principal concern was for my baggage, which has no direction, and is liable to get lost— After returning to Mrs: Decharms’s, Mr: John Vaughan called on me, as did Dr: Rush— The object of the latter was to inform me of a conversation which he had with Mr: Madison, the Secretary of State in the course of the last Summer, respecting me. Mr: Madison he said had express’d himself in very favourable terms, of me; and had told him that the President’s opinion of me was equally advantageous; & that it was his wish to employ me on some mission abroad, if I was desirous of it— The Doctor therefore intimated that I might govern myself accordingly, and take such measures to manifest my views as I should think expedient. I told him that I had heretofore received suggestions of a similar nature— That I was obliged to Mr: Jefferson, and Mr: Madison, for their good opinion— That I never had, and I hoped never should ask for any office of any Man; and certainly never should sollicit Mr: Jefferson, for any place whatsoever— That all I could say to him was that if Mr: Jefferson should nominate me for any Office abroad to which he thought me competent, I would not refuse it merely because the nomination should come from him— He said this assurance was entirely satisfactory; and that he believed the apprehension of a disdainful refusal, was the only thing which could deter Mr: Jefferson, from offering me an appointment— I assured him there was no Office in the President’s gift, for which I had any wish, and that without being rich, I possessed the means of maintaining my family, without feeling the necessity of any public Station.— He then made some remarks on the obligation a citizen is under to serve the public in places for which he is qualified, and concluded in complimentary terms, which I need not repeat, and ought to forget— I have no doubt but the Doctor’s intentions in this conversation were as friendly to me as possible, and that it was dictated entirely by his good wishes; but I am to remember,
that upwards of four years ago, when I first returned from Berlin, Coll: Smith told me that Mr: Jefferson had spoken of me, just in the same manner; and yet within twelve months afterwards he removed me from the Office of Commissioner of bankruptcy; which I held under the appointment of Judge Davis— I am also to remember the conversation, which I had with Mr: Jefferson the 23d: of November last year, and then reduce to their true value all these professions of regard and esteem, and of a wish to employ me in public Office— I spent this day somewhat heavily; and in compulsive idleness: attended about an hour at the Supreme Court of the State, which this day, commenced its Session; judge Yates presiding; this afternoon called upon Mr: Tracy; early in the Evening upon Mr: Dennie; and spent the last part of the Evening at Mr: Hopkinson’s; with Messrs: Ewing, Dennie, Meredith, & R. Rush. It was almost Midnight before the party broke up.

26. At 7 this morning, we embarked on board the Newcastle Packet, Caroline, Captain Weldon; but having lost the opportunity of yesterday’s wind, which carried that vessel down in five hours, we were all this day becalmed; and twice when the tide turned against us, obliged to anchor, for six hours at a time— The vessel was over-charged with passengers, and when Night came on; not more than half of them could be provided with beds— I slept the whole Night, upon one of the benches— Among the Passengers, were Mr: Tracy, a french Lady, Madame Cottineau, with Mademoiselle Brebire, and a Captain Callender of Philadelphia; all of whom were very agreeable; and contributed to alleviate the tediousness of the time— The little Wind we had, was directly contrary, through the whole day, and Night.

27. After a passage of twenty-four hours, we landed at Newcastle this morning, soon after day-light; and I found all my baggage safely stowed in a Store at the wharf; without any additional charge made— We breakfasted at the Inn, at Newcastle, and at 9 O’Clock, 18 of the passengers from Philadelphia, proceeded in two Stages to French-town— This place we reached soon after 12 at noon, and immediately went on board the Packet Jefferson, Captain Trip— The wind was still very light, and directly a-head, but we sailed just after one O’Clock; with about 35 passengers on board, eight or nine of whom were ladies. We had fine weather; but as night came on, and we got into Chesapeak-Bay the wind blew very fresh, and there was a heavy swell, which with the wind a-head, kept the vessel in such violent motion, that a great part of the Company were Sea-Sick. The accommodations of beds in the vessel were not sufficient for half the number of the Passengers, and I was again up the whole Night— About 1. o’clock in the morning we doubled North-point and entered Petapsco river, twelve miles below Baltimore— From which time the water was smooth, and the wind light— Between 3 and 4 in the morning, we landed at the wharf in Baltimore; and

28. Mr: Tracy, Captain Callender, and the ladies with me, immediately went up to Evans’s Inn; where we found some difficulty to get in; and when there were obliged to sit in the long-room, untill 8 in the morning, before we could get any beds. Some of the Company in the house, then having departed in the Stages, we took their beds and rested two or three hours, but I could get no sleep— We rose and breakfasted about 11— Coll: Howard called upon Mr: Tracy, and we went to visit Mr: Hindman, formerly a member of Congress from this State— We met judge Chase, on horseback in the Street, and he stop’d us to inveigh bitterly against the people of this Country, for having witnessed his impeachment with so much indifference— Nay, he verily believed a majority of them would have been glad to see him convicted.— We dined at Evans’s; and in the afternoon, with the ladies I called upon Mr: William Pinckney; with whom I left the business, Mr: Boylston committed to me before I left Boston.— Mr: Pinckney tells me that he finds the practice of the law extremely profitable, and since his return has been already engaged in business worth an average of ten thousand dollars a year— We return’d to Evans’s, for the Evening, which we made a short one. Mr: Tracy was very unwell; having long been in ill-health, and being over-fatigued by the loss of two Nights repose in succession— We had a visit from Mr: Hindman.

29. We engaged an extra Stage to take us on from Baltimore to Washington; for Mr: Tracy, and my family— But Mr: Israel Smith, a Senator, and Mr: Chittenden a member of the house of Representatives from Vermont, arriving this
morning, and being desirous to proceed immediately, we gave them places with us.— We parted at Baltimore from Captain Callender, whom we had found a very agreeable companion; and who is going to Norfolk where he has a ship in which he is going to France— We left Evans’s between 7 and 8— Dined at Ross’s; and arrived at Washington just at Sun-set— The Gentlemen with us stopp’d at Stelle’s new Hotel; and we immediately came to Mr: Hellen’s where we found him, and all the family Well.

30. Paid visits this morning to the President, whom I found at home, and to the Secretaries of State and the Navy, whom I did not see— Called also on Mr: Otis at his Office, where I met Mr: Plumer.— At the President’s door, I met Mr: Israel Smith and Mr: Gaillard who were on the same visit as myself— The President mentioned a late act of hostility committed by a french privateer near Charleston South Carolina, and said that we ought to assume as a principle, that the neutrality of our territory should extend to the Gulf-Stream; which was a natural boundary; and within which we ought not to suffer any hostility to be committed.— Mr: Gaillard observed, that on a former occasion in Mr Jefferson’s correspondence with Genet, and by an Act of Congress at that period we had seemed only to claim the usual distance of three miles from the Coast; but the President replied that he had then assumed that principle, because Genet by his intemperance forced us to fix on some point, and we were not then prepared to assert the claim of jurisdiction to the extent we are in reason entitled to; but he had then taken care expressly to reserve the subject for future consideration, with a view to this same doctrine for which he now contends— I observed that it might be well before we ventured to assume a claim so broad, to wait for a time when we should have a force competent to maintain it.— But in the meantime he said it was advisable to squint at it— And to accustom the Nations of Europe to the idea, that we should claim it in future.— The subject was not pushed any further— I called on Mr: Skipwith, and had some conversation with him respecting Mr: Boylstons demand; but he could give me no satisfactory information— I called at the Office of Mr: Gallatin, the Secretary of the Treasury, but he was not there.— We spent part of the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s.
Day. The first part of this month was employed like those which preceded it— The last three weeks I have been travelling; and of course led a life, of no regular order.
